Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Linking Livestock Markets and Grazing Practices with the Nutritional Ecology of Grasses and Locusts Under Alternative Property Rights Regimes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research has recently shown that overgrazing of livestock in a grassland in China lowered the nitrogen content of the grasses and that this caused a rise in the abundance of a locust likely to lead to locust swarms. This proposal will test whether this is also true for related species of locust in Australia and western Africa, and link both grazing practices and locust swarms to economics and social policy in the three contrasting regions. Three biologists and three social scientists will team up to help answer: (1) How do insect-nutrient relations and livestock grazing strategies interact to affect food prices, food security, and rangeland degradation? (2) How do property rights regimes affect the adaptive capacity of societies to respond to the link between overgrazing and locust outbreaks? Because both market forces and locust swarms operate over long distances, these effects are likely to be global.

Locust outbreaks have had devastating effects on food security, impacting crop and livestock yields. This proposal aims to develop new, sustainable strategies to understand and manage locust outbreaks, accounting for feedbacks among ecological, agricultural, and economic systems. Results will be translated directly into management and policy recommendations through collaborations with agricultural agencies. The project will also strengthen international scientific collaboration, train undergraduate and graduate students, and develop a multi-media outreach program for K-12 students and teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals addressed

  • Understand how livestock grazing influences locust outbreaks through changes in plant nutrition in closely related locusts found in China, Australia, and Senegal
  • Develop models describing feedbacks among locusts, nitrogen cycling, and grassland management.
  • Derive theoretical predictions of adaptive human behavioral responses to locust dynamics through time and over space under different property regimes
  • Understand how locust outbreaks impact livelihood outcomes, livestock markets, and grazing decisions
  • Generate livestock enterprise budgets to calculate profit per animal unit sold
  • Compare local grassland management institutions (China, Senegal, Australia) and their ability to suppress locust outbreaks
  • Compare livestock management and market responses to locust outbreaks across grassland management institutions (China, Senegal, and Australia)
  • Understand household grazing institutions and decision making, in particular how (or if) households incorporate locusts into grazing decisions Determine economic shocks to the meat sector due to locust outbreaks

 

Summary numbers

  • Peer reviewed publications: 15 published, 3 in review, 5 in preparation
  • National and international presentations: 54
  • Students trained: 3 high school, 10 graduate, 20 undergraduate
  • Postdocs trained: 2
  • Organizations collaborated with: 15 organizations across 5 countries

 

Intellectual Merit

This project integrates novel fundamental research from multiple disciplines to improve our ability to manage social-ecological systems. In doing so, it is one of the first to apply both highly-controlled lab and field-based techniques to connect physiological mechanisms regulating locust outbreaks and migration to agricultural practices and livelihoods.

 

We are one of the first groups to conduct field and lab-based comparative physiology on non-model locust species across multiple continents. We are uncovering the physiological and ecological and nutritional mechanisms responsible for insect outbreaks and migration. Our field demonstrations showing that many locust species are actually harmed by excessive nitrogen is becoming a new paradigm for plant-insect interaction research.

 

Research on this project is also developing new insights into the interaction between endogenous environmental risks and property rights. We are learning about novel feedbacks between livestock production (and thus grassland conditions), policy mechanisms, and land tenure institutions. While property rights have strengthened over the past two decades in Inner Mongolia, the ‘tragedy of the commons’ has not been avoided and looks to be only exacerbated in this setting. This seems due to the dynamic interactions in this social-ecological system, namely that markets are providing ways to break traditional social-ecological feedback mechanisms that kept the system self-regulating. We are also finding that government policy intervention may provide herders with less assurance of land rights, thus unwittingly incentivizing overstocking by inducing herders to think in more short-term time horizons. We are one of the first groups to have detailed financial information at a farm or herder level to better understand these tradeoffs between stocking rates, weather events, and financial decisions to provide more beneficial grazing management recommendations.

 

Broader Impacts

Training: Through this grant, 35 trainees at Arizona State University, Colorado State University, McGill University, and Yale University have had significant opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science.

 

Outreach: We have been invited to present our research at numerous venues as an example of a complex sustainability challenge. A few examples include ASU Homecoming, ASU’s Sustainability Teachers' Academy; ASU Prep Academy High School sustainability course; McGill and the greater Montreal community events; and others.

 

Community impact: Throughout this project, we worked integratively with local and national organizations in the regions where we conducted research. We met with partners regularly to discuss research design and disseminated results through culturally-appropriate mechanisms. For example, for the farming communities in Senegal, M.S. student Mira Word created pamphlets in French and Wolof (the local language) describing our project and the results. We held town hall meetings at the two villages where we collected data in 2016. We handed out pamphlets, discussed results, and received feedback from the farmers and village leaders. We held meetings with the Senegal Plant Protection Directorate (DPV) where we discussed further ways to integrate our research and DPV objectives and activities.

 

Locusts continue to have devastating impacts on agriculture and food security around the globe and especially in subsistence farming communities. Currently, best practices include diligent monitoring for early outbreaks and targeted control involving pesticide application. However, chemical pesticides can be ineffective and have far-reaching human and environmental health impacts. Additionally, locusts are a continental-level problem that requires coordinated responses across boundaries by individuals and governments. Our team’s research has paved the way for an innovative interdisciplinary, systems, and applied approach that targets sustainable land use as a tool. This results of this NSF CNH grant are currently being translated into practice by members of this team through a USAID OFDA project in Senegal. In addition, this project laid the groundwork for developing the Global Locust Initiative at ASU. This initiative has three objectives: Advancing fundamental and applied research, Creating a global network, and Developing On-the-Ground Solutions with Local Collaborators. (https://sustainability.asu.edu/global-locust-initiative/)
